intro: Sidalcea neomexicana var. parviflora, commonly known as the narrowleaf checker-mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is characterized by its small, pale pink to white flowers. The plant has narrow, hairy leaves and produces seed pods that split open to release tiny seeds. It is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. This variety is often found in desert environments and is adapted to thrive in low-nutrient soils.
